Real-Time updates are supported in later versions of April 2020. And I found it in the official [docs](https://clickhouse.tech/docs/en/sql-reference/statements/alter/update/).

Hi,

Here are the steps I took:
1. Initialise a new project: npm init -y
2. Install skywalking-client-js: npm install skywalking-client-js --save-dev
3. Create index.js and add the following code:

```
import ClientMonitor from 'skywalking-client-js';
ClientMonitor.register({
  collector: 'http://127.0.0.1:8080',
  service: 'local',
  pagePath: '/',
  serviceVersion: 'v1.0.0',
});
```

4. Run node index

Here are my node and npm versions in case you need them:
skywalking-client % node --version
v15.6.0
skywalking-client % npm --version
7.4.0

```yaml
version: '3.8'
services:
  oap:
    image: apache/skywalking-oap-server:8.3.0-es7
    container_name: oap
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 12800:12800
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "/skywalking/bin/swctl ch"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 3
      start_period: 40s
    environment:
      SW_STORAGE: h2
      SW_HEALTH_CHECKER: default
      SW_TELEMETRY: prometheus
      SW_PROMETHEUS_FETCHER: default
  ui:
    image: apache/skywalking-ui:8.3.0
    container_name: ui
    depends_on:
      - oap
    links:
      - oap
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 8080:8080
    environment:
      SW_OAP_ADDRESS: oap:12800
```

Make sure you have enough nodes (Kubernetes nodes) or specify less ElasticSearch replicas, otherwise the ES cluster won't work properly. This is more a Kubernetes cluster issue IMO, if you only have one VM to test, I suggest using KinD (Kubernetes in docker) to set up multiple virtual nodes. Or if ES is not what you want to test, using H2 as storage is another option (set storageType to h2 and elasticsearch.enabled=false IIRC, no PC at hand now)
